citations.narrative:
On February 24, 2024 (bird ID #: MU03) and March 6, 2024 (bird ID #: MU39), during public exhibition, two female
parakeets (one on each day) died in the aviary after being stepped on by a guest. Inadequate handling of animals during
periods of public exhibition can jeopardize the health and well-being of animals and the public alike. During public
exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient
distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals and the public.
The licensee corrected this issue by creating and utilizing a deterrent for the birds to keep them off the ground in the area
where the public stands.
Correct by: April 11, 2024

At the time of the inspection, there was exposed gridwall, metal framework overlying the dirt of the entire African Crested
porcupine (one male and one female) enclosure, whereby there were large gaps both between and underneath the
framework. The exposed metal framework, as well as the surrounding gaps/holes (some of which were dirt holes dug by
the porcupines) pose an entrapment/injury risk to the animals contained. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities must
be structurally sound and must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.
Correct by: May 9, 2024

Inside of the aviary was a large, industrial-style fan that was actively running at full speed with the cord dangling, whereby
approximately forty free-flighted parakeets had direct access to – and were landing on – the fan and/or cord. Equipment
within primary enclosures that is not designed and/or utilized in a safe manner, could directly injure the animals contained
therein. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury.
Correct by: April 16, 2024

A black metal cage, measuring approximately 40 (L) x 37 (W) x 20 (D) inches in size, housed thirty parakeets with
insufficient perch space to accommodate all birds contained therein. A number of the birds were perching along the bars
of the cage instead. Failure to include a sufficient amount of perch space could negatively impact the health and well-
being of the animals via stress, compatibility, and injuries, among other things. If the enclosure houses birds that rest by
perching, there must be perches available that are appropriate to the age and species of bird housed therein and a
sufficient number of perches of appropriate size, shape, strength, texture, and placement to comfortably hold all the birds
in the primary enclosure simultaneously, including birds that are ranked low in a dominance hierarchy.
Correct by: April 14, 2024

At the time of inspection there were approximately forty free-flighted parakeets in the open aviary that were seen mating,
however there were no nest boxes present. Lack of sufficient structures and materials to support species typical behavior
can negatively impact the health and the well-being of the animals contained therein. When exhibitors breed their birds,
such birds must be provided with structures (including a sufficient number of structures) and/or materials that meet the
reproductive needs of the species during the appropriate season or time periods.
Correct by: April 25, 2024

The black cage in the aviary, which housed thirty parakeets, contained only one water bowl – located on the floor of the
cage underneath the perches – which contained a significant amount (approximately 40-50% of the bowl) of feces.
Accumulation of feces within the water bowl can negatively affect the health and well-being of the birds contained therein.
Potable water must be provided in sufficient quantity to every bird housed at the facility and water receptacles must be
kept clean and sanitized in accordance with 3.158 as often as necessary to keep them clean and free of contamination.
Correct by: April 12, 2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The wooden rafters throughout the aviary, as well as the black metal cage housing the thirty newer parakeets, had an
excessive accumulation of feces on them, as the free-flighted parakeets would use them as perches. Accumulation of
feces and lack of proper and frequent cleaning could increase disease hazards and soiling of the birds contained therein.
Excreta must be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent accumulation of feces, to prevent
soiling of the birds contained in the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.
Correct by: April 18, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
William Snow, SUPERVISORY VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Gustavo Soberano, Assistant Director n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On February 24, 2024 (bird ID #: MU03) and March 6, 2024 (bird ID #: MU39), during public exhibition, two female 
parakeets (one on each day) died in the aviary after being stepped on by a guest. Inadequate handling of animals during 
periods of public exhibition can jeopardize the health and well-being of animals and the public alike. During public 
exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient 
distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals and the public. 
The licensee corrected this issue by creating and utilizing a deterrent for the birds to keep them off the ground in the area 
where the public stands.  
 
Correct by: April 11, 2024 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
At the time of the inspection, there was exposed gridwall, metal framework overlying the dirt of the entire African Crested 
porcupine (one male and one female) enclosure, whereby there were large gaps both between and underneath the 
framework. The exposed metal framework, as well as the surrounding gaps/holes (some of which were dirt holes dug by

be structurally sound and must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.

Inside of the aviary was a large, industrial-style fan that was actively running at full speed with the cord dangling, whereby

therein. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury.

Correct by: April 16, 2024 
3.153(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
A black metal cage, measuring approximately 40 (L) x 37 (W) x 20 (D) inches in size, housed thirty parakeets with 
insufficient perch space to accommodate all birds contained therein. A number of the birds were perching along the bars 
of the cage instead. Failure to include a sufficient amount of perch space could negatively impact the health and well-
being of the animals via stress, compatibility, and injuries, among other things. If the enclosure houses birds that rest by

3.153(b)(3)

At the time of inspection there were approximately forty free-flighted parakeets in the open aviary that were seen mating, 
however there were no nest boxes present. Lack of sufficient structures and materials to support species typical behavior 
can negatively impact the health and the well-being of the animals contained therein. When exhibitors breed their birds,

3.156 
   
Watering 
The black cage in the aviary, which housed thirty parakeets, contained only one water bowl – located on the floor of the 
cage underneath the perches – which contained a significant amount (approximately 40-50% of the bowl) of feces. 
Accumulation of feces within the water bowl can negatively affect the health and well-being of the birds contained therein. 
Potable water must be provided in sufficient quantity to every bird housed at the facility and water receptacles must be 
kept clean and sanitized in accordance with 3.158 as often as necessary to keep them clean and free of contamination.  
 
Correct by: April 12, 2024 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The wooden rafters throughout the aviary, as well as the black metal cage housing the thirty newer parakeets, had an 
excessive accumulation of feces on them, as the free-flighted parakeets would use them as perches. Accumulation of 
feces and lack of proper and frequent cleaning could increase disease hazards and soiling of the birds contained therein.

Excreta must be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent accumulation of feces, to prevent 
soiling of the birds contained in the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.  
 
Correct by: April 18, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

Gustavo Soberano, Assistant Director n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
